title: Further properties of a function of Ogg and Ligozat

title_detail.value: Further properties of a function of Ogg and Ligozat

summary:
Certain identities of Ramanujan may be succinctly expressed in terms of the
rational function w_N(g) = w_N(f) - 1/w_N(f) on the modular curve X_0(N), where
f is a certain modular unit on the Nebentypus cover X_\chi(N) introduced by Ogg
and Ligozat for N prime congruent to 1 (mod 4) and w_N is the Fricke
involution. These correspond to levels N = 5, 13, where the genus of X_0(N) is
zero. In this paper we produce some analogs of these identities for each w_N(g)
such that X_0(N) has genus 1, 2, and also for each h = g + w_N(g) such that the
Atkin-Lehner quotient X_0+(N) has genus 1, 2. We also found that if n is the
degree of the field of definition F of the non-trivial zeros of the latter,
then the degree of the normal closure of F over Q is the n-th solution of
Singmaster's Problem.

summary_detail.value:
Certain identities of Ramanujan may be succinctly expressed in terms of the
rational function w_N(g) = w_N(f) - 1/w_N(f) on the modular curve X_0(N), where
f is a certain modular unit on the Nebentypus cover X_\chi(N) introduced by Ogg
and Ligozat for N prime congruent to 1 (mod 4) and w_N is the Fricke
involution. These correspond to levels N = 5, 13, where the genus of X_0(N) is
zero. In this paper we produce some analogs of these identities for each w_N(g)
such that X_0(N) has genus 1, 2, and also for each h = g + w_N(g) such that the
Atkin-Lehner quotient X_0+(N) has genus 1, 2. We also found that if n is the
degree of the field of definition F of the non-trivial zeros of the latter,
then the degree of the normal closure of F over Q is the n-th solution of
Singmaster's Problem.

author: Carlos Castano-Bernard
fulltext:
arXiv:math/0603016v1 [math.NT] 1 Mar 2006

FURTHER PROPERTIES OF A FUNCTION OF OGG
AND LIGOZAT
CARLOS CASTAÑO-BERNARD
Abstract. Certain identities of Ramanujan may be succinctly
expressed in terms of the rational function ğχ = f ̆χ − f ̆1 on the
χ
modular curve X0 (N ), where f ̆χ = wN fχ and fχ is a certain modular unit on the Nebentypus cover Xχ (N ) introduced by Ogg and
Ligozat for prime N ≡ 1 (mod 4) and wN is the Fricke involution. These correspond to levels N = 5, 13, where the genus gN of
X0 (N ) is zero. In this paper we study a slightly more general kind
of relations for each ğχ such that X0 (N ) has genus gN = 1, 2, and
also for each hχ = gχ + ğχ such that the Atkin-Lehner quotient
+
X0+ (N ) has genus gN
= 1, 2. It turns out that if n is the degree of
the field of definition F of the non-trivial zeros of the latter, then
the degree of the normal closure of F over Q is the n-th solution
of Singmaster's Problem.

Contents
1. Introduction
2. Background material
3. Variant of Ligozat's construction
4. Infinite products and Fourier expansions
5. On some identities of Ramanujan
6. The zeros of hχ for small N
7. Final remarks
References

1
3
4
6
8
11
14
14

1. Introduction
Let X0 (N) be the usual compactification of the coarse moduli space
Y0 (N) of isomorphism classes of pairs (E, E ′ ) of elliptic curves E and
E ′ linked by a cyclic isogeny of degree N. Suppose N is a prime number
such that N ≡ 1 (mod 4) and let Xχ (N) −→ X0 (N) be the Nebentypus covering that corresponds to the kernel of the quadratic character
χ on (Z/NZ)× as in (7.5.14) and (7.5.15) of Shimura's book [15]. In
Mazur's paper [11, pp. 107, 108] it may be found a construction due
to Ligozat of a modular unit fχ on Xχ (N). Certain identities due to
1

 2

CARLOS CASTAÑO-BERNARD

Ramanujan may be succinctly expressed in terms of the rational function ğχ = f ̆χ − f ̆1 in Q(X0 (N)) as ğχ (τ ) = P (t(τ )), where t(τ ) is a
χ
certain modular unit on X0 (N), P (T )Z[T ] is a polynomial of degree
1, f ̆χ = wN fχ , and wN is the Fricke involution. (See Section 5.) In
these cases the genus gN of X0 (N) is gN = 0. It turns out that for
X0 (N) of genus gN > 0, identities of the form ğχ = P (t(τ )) with
P (T )Q[T ] arbitrary are unlikely. So the natural analogs of these identities for genus gN > 0 are perhaps of the form ğχ = P (X, Y ), for
some "canonically defined" rational functions X and Y of X0 (N). We
suggest such identities for ğχ for gN = 1 and 2, and also for the rational function hχ = gχ + ğχ ∈ Q(X0+ (N)), where gχ = fχ − f1χ and
X0+ (N) = X0 (N)/{1, wN } is the Atkin-Lehner quotient of X0 (N) de+
fined by the involution wN and X0+ (N) has genus gN
= 1 and 2. With
the help of some Gröbner basis algorithms, the latter identities yield
the field of definition of each of the zeros of hχ . These turn out
√ to
be either Q or a finite extension F of the real quadratic field Q( N );
the field extension F/Q has degree n = 21 B2,χ , if N ≡ 1 (mod 8) and
n = 21 B2,χ − 1, if N ≡ 5 (mod 8), where Bm,χ is the m-th generalised
Bernoulli number attached to the character χ. Moreover, in each of
these cases the Galois group G = G(F nrm /Q) of the normal closure
F nrm of F over the rationals Q is the wreath product G = S n2 ≀ C2 of
the symmetric group S n2 of permutations of n2 objects and the cyclic
group of order two C2 . This means that in each of these cases the Galois group G has order #(G) = 2( n2 )!, which turns out to be the n-th
solution of Singmaster's Problem [16].
Organisation of the paper. In order to make the exposition as
self contained as possible we include some standard results on modular
curves and modular units tailored to our needs, in Section 2. We
also include a variant of Ligozat's construction based on an extension
of a classical identity used by Gauss in his third proof of the Law of
Quadratic Reciprocity, in Section 3. The main results are contained
in Section 5, the gN = 1 case (i.e. N = 17) and the gN = 2 case
(i.e. N = 29, 37), and in Section 6, the field of definition of the zeros
+
+
of hχ (τ ) for gN
= 1 (i.e. N = 37, 53, 61, 89, 101), and for gN
= 2 (i.e.
N = 73). The paper concludes with a conjecture and an open problem,
in Section 7.
Acknowledgements. Our computer calculations were performed
with the help of the computer algebra packages Magma [2], Macaulay2 [6],
and Pari [13] installed on GNU/Linux computers. We wish to thank
the Department of Pure Mathematics and Mathematical Statistics of
the University of Cambridge for the access to these packages. We also
wish to express our gratitude to my wife, Concepción Vargas-Chávez

 FURTHER PROPERTIES OF A FUNCTION OF OGG AND LIGOZAT

3

and my brother, Ricardo Castaño-Bernard for their constant support
and encouragement.

From the point of view of the function theory of the curve X0 (N)
Equation 5.1 and Equation 5.2 are essentially obvious. Indeed, consider
the well-known fact that the divisor of poles of t(τ ) is concentrated at
the cusp ∞ with degree vN = 1−N
, and that the divisor of poles of
m
gχ (τ ) is concentrated also at the cusp ∞, but with degree vχ = 21 B2,χ .
Assume N = 5, 13. Thus both, the modular unit t(τ ) and the rational
function gχ (τ ) have valence one. So there must be a polynomial P (T ) ∈
Z[T ] of degree one such that gχ (τ ) = P (t(τ )), which may be explicitly
obtained using the principal part of the q-expansion of each of these
functions.
An equation of the form gχ (τ ) = P (t(τ )), for some polynomial
P (T ) ∈ Q[T ], for prime level N ≡ 1 (mod 4) greater than 13 seems
unlikely. Indeed, experimental evidence suggests that for such levels
function f ̆χ (τ ) also appears in connection
with the Rogers-Ramanujan's
con

N > 13 the necessary divisibility condition vN | vχ holds are exactly

By subtracting from gχ (τ ) the relevant powers of t(τ ), for each level N
in the above table it is easy to see that a relation of the form gχ (τ ) =
P (t(τ )) is not possible.
For X0 (N) of genus gN = 1 it is not difficult compute explicit expressions of the form gχ (τ ) = P (X(τ ), X(τ )), where P (X, Y ) ∈ Q[X, Y ],
and X and Y are given generators of the function field of X0 (N) over
Q. Indeed, let X and Y be the coordinate functions of the modular
parametrisation of X0 (N), regarded as an elliptic curve. Then by computing a few terms of the q-expansion of gχ (τ ) (see Theorem 4.2) it is
easy to find an integer a(r, s), and positive integers r and s such that
the rational function gχ (τ ) − a(r, s)X r Y s has a pole at ∞ of degree less
than that of gχ (τ ) at ∞. Proceeding recursively, we may arrive at a
function with no poles that vanishes at ∞, thus the zero function on
X0 (N). This yields the desired expression gχ = P (X, Y ).
Example 5.1. Suppose N = 17. Using Cremona's Tables [3] we may
see that the curve X0 (N) of genus gN = 1 is isomorphic to curve 17A1.
Thus it has a global minimal Weierstrass model
Y 2 + XY + Y = X 3 − X 2 − X − 14,
and a modular parametrisation
1
1
X(τ ) = 2 + + 1 + O(q),
q
q
1
2
2
Y (τ ) = − 3 − 2 − − 3 + O(q).
q
q
q
Since ğχ has exactly one pole, and ğχ = − q12 − 1q − 2 + O(q), it follows
that
ğχ (τ ) = −(X(τ ) + 1).
For X0 (N) of genus gN = 2 the situation is nearly as simple.
Example 5.2. Suppose N = 29. The modular curve X0 (N) is an

A consequence of Theorem 3.2 is that hχ may be regarded as a rational

hχ (τ ) = P (X(τ ), X(τ )), where P (X, Y ) ∈ Q[X, Y ], and X and Y are

Note that the degree of each of the above polynomials is one less
than the degree of the divisor of zeros of hχ (τ ) for N = 37, 53, 61,
and 101. These are exactly the prime levels such that N ≡ 5 (mod 8)
considered just above. This is explained by the existence of a "trivial"
rational zero of hχ (τ ).
Lemma 6.2. If N ≡ 5 (mod 8) then hχ (τ ) vanishes at the common
image in X0+ (N) of the two Heegner points of discriminant D = −4 on
the curve X0 (N).

element of the Galois group G(Xχ (N)/X0 (N)) may be represented by
the matrix


7. Final remarks
Some computations we performed on the above polynomials pN (T )
are consistent with the following.
Conjecture 7.1. The field of definition each of the zeros√of hχ is either
Q or an extension F of the real quadratic field k = Q( N ) of degree
n = 21 B2,χ , if N ≡ 1 (mod 8) and n = 12 B2,χ − 1, if N ≡ 5 (mod 8),
where Bm,χ is the m-th generalised Bernoulli number attached to the
character χ.
In other words we conjecture that the Galois group is in a sense
as "large as possible". Numerical evidence suggests that the above
+
conjecture is true also for the genus gN
= 0 case, i.e. for N = 17, 29,
and N = 41. It is hoped that a more extensive numerical evidence
+
from higher genus examples, e.g. gN
= 3 may perhaps shed some light
on the nature of phenomena.
Finally, perhaps it is worth investigating if this potential connexion
with Singmaster's Problem [16] might suggest a yet to be discovered,
interesting combinatorial aspect of the Galois group G = G(F nrm /Q)
of the normal closure F nrm of F over the rationals Q.
